source_schema.name: ADMISSIONS
source_schema.description: The ADMISSIONS table gives information regarding a patient’s admission to the hospital.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: The ADMISSIONS table can be linked to the PATIENTS table using SUBJECT_ID

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: Each row of this table contains a unique HADM_ID, which represents a single patient’s admission to the hospital. HADM_ID ranges from 1000000 - 1999999.

columns.name: admittime
columns.column_description: provides the date and time the patient was admitted to the hospital

columns.name: dischtime
columns.column_description: provides the date and time the patient was discharged from the hospital

columns.name: deathtime
columns.column_description: If applicable, DEATHTIME provides the time of in-hospital death for the patient. Note that DEATHTIME is only present if the patient died in-hospital, and is almost always the same as the patient’s DISCHTIME

columns.name: admission_type
columns.column_description: describes the type of the admission

columns.name: admission_location
columns.column_description: provides information about the previous location of the patient prior to arriving at the hospital

columns.name: insurance
columns.column_description: describe patient demographics.

columns.name: language
columns.column_description: describe patient demographics.

columns.name: religion
columns.column_description: describe patient demographics.

columns.name: marital_status
columns.column_description: describe patient demographics.

columns.name: ethnicity
columns.column_description: describe patient demographics.

columns.name: edregtime
columns.column_description: Time that the patient was registered from the emergency department

columns.name: edouttime
columns.column_description: Time that the patient was discharged from the emergency department

columns.name: diagnosis
columns.column_description: The DIAGNOSIS column provides a preliminary, free text diagnosis for the patient on hospital admission

columns.name: hospital_expire_flag
columns.column_description: This indicates whether the patient died within the given hospitalization

target_schema.name: VISIT_OCCURRENCE
target_schema.description: This table contains Events where Persons engage with the healthcare system for a duration of time. They are often also called “Encounters”. Visits are defined by a configuration of circumstances under which they occur, such as (i) whether the patient comes to a healthcare institution, the other way around, or the interaction is remote, (ii) whether and what kind of trained medical staff is delivering the service during the Visit, and (iii) whether the Visit is transient or for a longer period involving a stay in bed.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit.

columns.name: visit_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field contains a concept id representing the kind of visit, like inpatient or outpatient. All concepts in this field should be standard and belong to the Visit domain.

columns.name: visit_start_date
columns.column_description: For inpatient visits, the start date is typically the admission date. For outpatient visits the start date and end date will be the same.

columns.name: visit_end_date
columns.column_description: For inpatient visits the end date is typically the discharge date.

columns.name: visit_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to understand the provenance of the visit record, or where the record comes from.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: There will only be one provider per visit record and the ETL document should clearly state how they were chosen (attending, admitting, etc.). If there are multiple providers associated with a visit in the source, this can be reflected in the event tables (CONDITION_OCCURRENCE, PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE, etc.) or in the VISIT_DETAIL table.

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: This field provides information about the care site where the visit took place.

columns.name: visit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the kind of visit that took place (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, etc.)

columns.name: admitted_from_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: discharge_to_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was discharged to home or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: preceding_visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to find the visit that occurred for the person prior to the given visit. There could be a few days or a few years in between.

target_schema.name: PERSON
target_schema.description: This table serves as the central identity management for all Persons in the database. It contains records that uniquely identify each person or patient, and some demographic information.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: It is assumed that every person with a different unique identifier is in fact a different person and should be treated independently.

columns.name: gender_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field is meant to capture the biological sex at birth of the Person. This field should not be used to study gender identity issues.

columns.name: year_of_birth
columns.column_description: Compute age using year_of_birth.

columns.name: death_datetime
columns.column_description: This field is the death date to be used in analysis, as determined by the ETL logic. Any additional information about a Person’s death is stored in the OBSERVATION table with the concept_id 4306655 or in the CONDITION_OCCURRENCE .

columns.name: race_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures race or ethnic background of the person.

columns.name: ethnicity_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures Ethnicity as defined by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) of the US Government: it distinguishes only between “Hispanic” and “Not Hispanic”. Races and ethnic backgrounds are not stored here.

columns.name: location_id
columns.column_description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person. Any prior locations are captured in the LOCATION_HISTORY table.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The Provider refers to the last known primary care provider (General Practitioner).

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: The Care Site refers to where the Provider typically provides the primary care.

columns.name: person_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to link back to persons in the source data. This is typically used for error checking of ETL logic.

columns.name: gender_source_value
columns.column_description: This field is used to store the biological sex of the person from the source data. It is not intended for use in standard analytics but for reference only.

columns.name: gender_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: Due to the small number of options, this tends to be zero.

columns.name: race_source_value
columns.column_description: This field is used to store the race of the person from the source data. It is not intended for use in standard analytics but for reference only.

columns.name: race_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: Due to the small number of options, this tends to be zero.

columns.name: ethnicity_source_value
columns.column_description: This field is used to store the ethnicity of the person from the source data. It is not intended for use in standard analytics but for reference only.

columns.name: ethnicity_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: Due to the small number of options, this tends to be zero.

source_schema.name: CALLOUT
source_schema.description: Information regarding when a patient was cleared for ICU discharge and when the patient was actually discharged.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: patient corresponding to the given call out event

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: hospital admission corresponding to the given call out event

columns.name: submit_wardid
columns.column_description: identifies the ward from which the request was submitted

columns.name: submit_careunit
columns.column_description: indicates whether the SUBMIT_WARDID corresponds to an ICU cost center, and if so, what type of ICU cost center.

columns.name: curr_wardid
columns.column_description: identifies the ward in which the patient resides when called out (i.e. prior to discharge/transfer)

columns.name: curr_careunit
columns.column_description: indicates which ICU cost center the CURR_WARDID corresponds to

columns.name: callout_wardid
columns.column_description: identifies the ward to which the patient should be discharged

columns.name: callout_service
columns.column_description: is the service under which the patient should be discharged

columns.name: request_tele
columns.column_description: binary indicator which request certain precautions for the patient in the subsequent ward where they will reside.

columns.name: request_resp
columns.column_description: binary indicator which request certain precautions for the patient in the subsequent ward where they will reside.

columns.name: request_cdiff
columns.column_description: binary indicator which request certain precautions for the patient in the subsequent ward where they will reside.

columns.name: request_mrsa
columns.column_description: binary indicator which request certain precautions for the patient in the subsequent ward where they will reside.

columns.name: request_vre
columns.column_description: binary indicator which request certain precautions for the patient in the subsequent ward where they will reside.

columns.name: callout_status
columns.column_description: indicates whether the call out is still active or not.

columns.name: callout_outcome
columns.column_description: indicating whether the patient finally called out (i.e. discharged) or not.

columns.name: discharge_wardid
columns.column_description: indicates the ward to which the patient was actually discharged.

columns.name: acknowledge_status
columns.column_description: indicates the response to the callout event

columns.name: createtime
columns.column_description: provides the time and date that the call out was initiated.

columns.name: updatetime
columns.column_description: provides the last time at which the call out event was updated.

columns.name: acknowledgetime
columns.column_description: is the time at which the call out was first acknowledged.

columns.name: outcometime
columns.column_description: is the time at which the CALLOUT_OUTCOME occurred.

columns.name: firstreservationtime
columns.column_description: provide information regarding ward reservations.

columns.name: currentreservationtime
columns.column_description: provide information regarding ward reservations.

target_schema.name: VISIT_DETAIL
target_schema.description: The VISIT_DETAIL table is an optional table used to represents details of each record in the parent VISIT_OCCURRENCE table. A good example of this would be the movement between units in a hospital during an inpatient stay or claim lines associated with a one insurance claim. For every record in the VISIT_OCCURRENCE table there may be 0 or more records in the VISIT_DETAIL table with a 1:n relationship where n may be 0. The VISIT_DETAIL table is structurally very similar to VISIT_OCCURRENCE table and belongs to the visit domain.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit detail.

columns.name: visit_detail_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field contains a concept id representing the kind of visit detail, like inpatient or outpatient. All concepts in this field should be standard and belong to the Visit domain.

columns.name: visit_detail_start_date
columns.column_description: This is the date of the start of the encounter. This may or may not be equal to the date of the Visit the Visit Detail is associated with.

columns.name: visit_detail_end_date
columns.column_description: This the end date of the patient-provider interaction.

columns.name: visit_detail_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to understand the provenance of the visit detail record, or where the record comes from.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: There will only be one provider per visit record and the ETL document should clearly state how they were chosen (attending, admitting, etc.). This is a typical reason for leveraging the VISIT_DETAIL table as even though each VISIT_DETAIL record can only have one provider, there is no limit to the number of VISIT_DETAIL records that can be associated to a VISIT_OCCURRENCE record.

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: This field provides information about the Care Site where the Visit Detail took place.

columns.name: visit_detail_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the kind of visit detail that took place (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, etc.)

columns.name: admitted_from_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: discharge_to_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit detail record. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was discharged to home or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: preceding_visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to find the visit detail that occurred for the person prior to the given visit detail record. There could be a few days or a few years in between.

columns.name: visit_detail_parent_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to find the visit detail that subsumes the given visit detail record. This is used in the case that a visit detail record needs to be nested beyond the VISIT_OCCURRENCE/VISIT_DETAIL relationship.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to link the VISIT_DETAIL record to its VISIT_OCCURRENCE.

target_schema.name: PROVIDER
target_schema.description: The PROVIDER table contains a list of uniquely identified healthcare providers. These are individuals providing hands-on healthcare to patients, such as physicians, nurses, midwives, physical therapists etc.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: It is assumed that every provider with a different unique identifier is in fact a different person and should be treated independently.

columns.name: npi
columns.column_description: This is the National Provider Number issued to health care providers in the US by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS).

columns.name: dea
columns.column_description: This is the identifier issued by the DEA, a US federal agency, that allows a provider to write prescriptions for controlled substances.

columns.name: specialty_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field either represents the most common specialty that occurs in the data or the most specific concept that represents all specialties listed, should the provider have more than one. This includes physician specialties such as internal medicine, emergency medicine, etc. and allied health professionals such as nurses, midwives, and pharmacists.

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: This is the CARE_SITE_ID for the location that the provider primarily practices in.

columns.name: gender_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field represents the recorded gender of the provider in the source data.

columns.name: provider_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to link back to providers in the source data. This is typically used for error checking of ETL logic.

columns.name: specialty_source_value
columns.column_description: This is the kind of provider or specialty as it appears in the source data. This includes physician specialties such as internal medicine, emergency medicine, etc. and allied health professionals such as nurses, midwives, and pharmacists.

columns.name: specialty_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is often zero as many sites use proprietary codes to store physician speciality.

columns.name: gender_source_value
columns.column_description: This is provider’s gender as it appears in the source data.

columns.name: gender_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is often zero as many sites use proprietary codes to store provider gender.

target_schema.name: MEASUREMENT
target_schema.description: The MEASUREMENT table contains records of Measurements, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a Person or Person’s sample. The MEASUREMENT table contains both orders and results of such Measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc. Measurements are stored as attribute value pairs, with the attribute as the Measurement Concept and the value representing the result. The value can be a Concept (stored in VALUE_AS_CONCEPT), or a numerical value (VALUE_AS_NUMBER) with a Unit (UNIT_CONCEPT_ID). The Procedure for obtaining the sample is housed in the PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE table, though it is unnecessary to create a PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE record for each measurement if one does not exist in the source data. Measurements differ from Observations in that they require a standardized test or some other activity to generate a quantitative or qualitative result. If there is no result, it is assumed that the lab test was conducted but the result was not captured.

columns.name: measurement_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to a Measurement record for a Person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate Measurements during the same Visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the measurement is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: measurement_concept_id
columns.column_description: The MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies.

columns.name: measurement_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the date of the measurement.

columns.name: measurement_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Measurement record, as in whether the measurement was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: operator_concept_id
columns.column_description: The meaning of Concept 4172703 for ‘=’ is identical to omission of a OPERATOR_CONCEPT_ID value. Since the use of this field is rare, it’s important when devising analyses to not to forget testing for the content of this field for values different from =.

columns.name: value_as_number
columns.column_description: This is the numerical value of the Result of the Measurement, if available. Note that measurements such as blood pressures will be split into their component parts i.e. one record for systolic, one record for diastolic.

columns.name: value_as_concept_id
columns.column_description: If the raw data gives a categorial result for measurements those values are captured and mapped to standard concepts in the ‘Meas Value’ domain.

columns.name: unit_concept_id
columns.column_description: There is currently no recommended unit for individual measurements, i.e. it is not mandatory to represent Hemoglobin a1C measurements as a percentage. UNIT_SOURCE_VALUES should be mapped to a Standard Concept in the Unit domain that best represents the unit as given in the source data.

columns.name: range_low
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: range_high
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with measurement record, e.g. the provider who ordered the test or the provider who recorded the result.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the Measurement occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Measurement occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: measurement_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the Measurement that occurred. For example, this could be an ICD10 or Read code.

columns.name: measurement_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the MEASUREMENT_SOURCE_VALUE and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Measurement necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the unit of the Measurement that occurred.

columns.name: value_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim result value of the Measurement from the source data .

target_schema.name: PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE
target_schema.description: This table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient with a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose.

columns.name: procedure_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: A system-generated unique identifier for each Procedure Occurrence.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the procedure is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: procedure_concept_id
columns.column_description: The PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies. This is the standard concept mapped from the source value which represents a procedure

columns.name: procedure_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the date the procedure occurred.

columns.name: procedure_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Procedure record, as in whether the procedure was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: modifier_concept_id
columns.column_description: The modifiers are intended to give additional information about the procedure but as of now the vocabulary is under review.

columns.name: quantity
columns.column_description: If the quantity value is omitted, a single procedure is assumed.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with the procedure record, e.g. the provider who performed the Procedure.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the procedure occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Procedure occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time of the Procedure the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: procedure_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the procedure that occurred. For example, this could be an CPT4 or OPCS4 code.

columns.name: procedure_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the procedure source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Procedure necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

target_schema.name: CONCEPT
target_schema.description: The Standardized Vocabularies contains records, or Concepts, that uniquely identify each fundamental unit of meaning used to express clinical information in all domain tables of the CDM. Concepts are derived from vocabularies, which represent clinical information across a domain (e.g. conditions, drugs, procedures) through the use of codes and associated descriptions. Some Concepts are designated Standard Concepts, meaning these Concepts can be used as normative expressions of a clinical entity within the OMOP Common Data Model and within standardized analytics. Each Standard Concept belongs to one domain, which defines the location where the Concept would be expected to occur within data tables of the CDM. Concepts can represent broad categories (like ‘Cardiovascular disease’), detailed clinical elements (‘Myocardial infarction of the anterolateral wall’) or modifying characteristics and attributes that define Concepts at various levels of detail (severity of a disease, associated morphology, etc.). Records in the Standardized Vocabularies tables are derived from national or international vocabularies such as SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, and LOINC, or custom Concepts defined to cover various aspects of observational data analysis.

columns.name: concept_id
columns.column_description: A unique identifier for each Concept across all domains.

columns.name: concept_name
columns.column_description: An unambiguous, meaningful and descriptive name for the Concept.

columns.name: domain_id
columns.column_description: A foreign key to the DOMAIN table the Concept belongs to.

columns.name: vocabulary_id
columns.column_description: A foreign key to the VOCABULARY table indicating from which source the Concept has been adapted.

columns.name: concept_class_id
columns.column_description: The attribute or concept class of the Concept. Examples are ‘Clinical Drug’, ‘Ingredient’, ‘Clinical Finding’ etc.

columns.name: standard_concept
columns.column_description: This flag determines where a Concept is a Standard Concept, i.e. is used in the data, a Classification Concept, or a non-standard Source Concept. The allowable values are ‘S’ (Standard Concept) and ‘C’ (Classification Concept), otherwise the content is NULL.

columns.name: concept_code
columns.column_description: The concept code represents the identifier of the Concept in the source vocabulary, such as SNOMED-CT concept IDs, RxNorm RXCUIs etc. Note that concept codes are not unique across vocabularies.

columns.name: valid_start_date
columns.column_description: The date when the Concept was first recorded. The default value is 1-Jan-1970, meaning, the Concept has no (known) date of inception.

columns.name: valid_end_date
columns.column_description: The date when the Concept became invalid because it was deleted or superseded (updated) by a new concept. The default value is 31-Dec-2099, meaning, the Concept is valid until it becomes deprecated.

columns.name: invalid_reason
columns.column_description: Reason the Concept was invalidated. Possible values are D (deleted), U (replaced with an update) or NULL when valid_end_date has the default value.

target_schema.name: CONCEPT
target_schema.description: The Standardized Vocabularies contains records, or Concepts, that uniquely identify each fundamental unit of meaning used to express clinical information in all domain tables of the CDM. Concepts are derived from vocabularies, which represent clinical information across a domain (e.g. conditions, drugs, procedures) through the use of codes and associated descriptions. Some Concepts are designated Standard Concepts, meaning these Concepts can be used as normative expressions of a clinical entity within the OMOP Common Data Model and within standardized analytics. Each Standard Concept belongs to one domain, which defines the location where the Concept would be expected to occur within data tables of the CDM. Concepts can represent broad categories (like ‘Cardiovascular disease’), detailed clinical elements (‘Myocardial infarction of the anterolateral wall’) or modifying characteristics and attributes that define Concepts at various levels of detail (severity of a disease, associated morphology, etc.). Records in the Standardized Vocabularies tables are derived from national or international vocabularies such as SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, and LOINC, or custom Concepts defined to cover various aspects of observational data analysis.

columns.name: loinc_code
columns.column_description: contains the LOINC code associated with the given ITEMID

source_schema.name: DATETIMEEVENTS
source_schema.description: Contains all date formatted data.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient hospital stay

columns.name: icustay_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient ICU stay

columns.name: charttime
columns.column_description: records the time at which an observation was charted, and is usually the closest proxy to the time the data was actually measured

columns.name: storetime
columns.column_description: records the time at which an observation was manually input or manually validated by a member of the clinical staff

columns.name: cgid
columns.column_description: is the identifier for the caregiver who validated the given measurement

target_schema.name: OBSERVATION
target_schema.description: The OBSERVATION table captures clinical facts about a Person obtained in the context of examination, questioning or a procedure. Any data that cannot be represented by any other domains, such as social and lifestyle facts, medical history, family history, etc. are recorded here. New to CDM v6.0 An Observation can now be linked to other records in the CDM instance using the fields OBSERVATION_EVENT_ID and OBS_EVENT_FIELD_CONCEPT_ID. To link another record to an Observation, the primary key goes in OBSERVATION_EVENT_ID (CONDITION_OCCURRENCE_ID, DRUG_EXPOSURE_ID, etc.) and the Concept representing the field where the OBSERVATION_EVENT_ID was taken from go in the OBS_EVENT_FIELD_CONCEPT_ID. For example, a CONDITION_OCCURRENCE of Asthma might be linked to an Observation of a family history of Asthma. In this case the CONDITION_OCCURRENCE_ID of the Asthma record would go in OBSERVATION_EVENT_ID of the family history record and the CONCEPT_ID 1147127 would go in OBS_EVENT_FIELD_CONCEPT_ID to denote that the OBSERVATION_EVENT_ID represents a CONDITION_OCCURRENCE_ID.

columns.name: observation_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to an Observation record for a Person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate Observations during the same Visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the Person for whom the Observation is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: observation_concept_id
columns.column_description: The OBSERVATION_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies.

columns.name: observation_date
columns.column_description: The date of the Observation. Depending on what the Observation represents this could be the date of a lab test, the date of a survey, or the date a patient’s family history was taken.

columns.name: observation_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Observation record, as in whether the measurement was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: value_as_number
columns.column_description: This is the numerical value of the Result of the Observation, if applicable and available. It is not expected that all Observations will have numeric results, rather, this field is here to house values should they exist.

columns.name: value_as_string
columns.column_description: This is the categorical value of the Result of the Observation, if applicable and available.

columns.name: value_as_concept_id
columns.column_description: It is possible that some records destined for the Observation table have two clinical ideas represented in one source code. This is common with ICD10 codes that describe a family history of some Condition, for example. In OMOP the Vocabulary breaks these two clinical ideas into two codes; one becomes the OBSERVATION_CONCEPT_ID and the other becomes the VALUE_AS_CONCEPT_ID. It is important when using the Observation table to keep this possibility in mind and to examine the VALUE_AS_CONCEPT_ID field for relevant information.

columns.name: qualifier_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field contains all attributes specifying the clinical fact further, such as as degrees, severities, drug-drug interaction alerts etc.

columns.name: unit_concept_id
columns.column_description: There is currently no recommended unit for individual observation concepts. UNIT_SOURCE_VALUES should be mapped to a Standard Concept in the Unit domain that best represents the unit as given in the source data.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with the observation record, e.g. the provider who ordered the test or the provider who recorded the result.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the Observation occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Observation occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: observation_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the Observation that occurred. For example, this could be an ICD10 or Read code.

columns.name: observation_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the OBSERVATION_SOURCE_VALUE and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Observation necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using OBSERVATION_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the unit of the Observation that occurred.

columns.name: qualifier_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the qualifier of the Observation that occurred.

columns.name: observation_event_id
columns.column_description: If the Observation record is related to another record in the database, this field is the primary key of the linked record.

columns.name: obs_event_field_concept_id
columns.column_description: If the Observation record is related to another record in the database, this field is the CONCEPT_ID that identifies which table the primary key of the linked record came from.

columns.name: value_as_datetime
columns.column_description: It is possible that some Observation records might store a result as a date value.

source_schema.name: DIAGNOSES_ICD
source_schema.description: Contains ICD diagnoses for patients, most notably ICD-9 diagnoses.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: Identifier which specify the patient

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: Identifier to a patient hospital stay

columns.name: seq_num
columns.column_description: provides the order in which the ICD diagnoses relate to the patient

columns.name: icd9_code
columns.column_description: contains the actual code corresponding to the diagnosis assigned to the patient for the given row.

target_schema.name: CONDITION_OCCURRENCE
target_schema.description: This table contains records of Events of a Person suggesting the presence of a disease or medical condition stated as a diagnosis, a sign, or a symptom, which is either observed by a Provider or reported by the patient.

columns.name: condition_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to a condition record for a person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate conditions during the same visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the condition is recorded.

columns.name: condition_concept_id
columns.column_description: The CONDITION_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies. This is the standard concept mapped from the source value which represents a condition

columns.name: condition_start_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the start date of the condition

columns.name: condition_end_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the end date of the condition

columns.name: condition_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Condition record, as in whether the condition was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: condition_status_concept_id
columns.column_description: This concept represents the point during the visit the diagnosis was given (admitting diagnosis, final diagnosis), whether the diagnosis was determined due to laboratory findings, if the diagnosis was exclusionary, or if it was a preliminary diagnosis, among others.

columns.name: stop_reason
columns.column_description: The Stop Reason indicates why a Condition is no longer valid with respect to the purpose within the source data. Note that a Stop Reason does not necessarily imply that the condition is no longer occurring.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with condition record, e.g. the provider who made the diagnosis or the provider who recorded the symptom.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the condition occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the condition occurred. For example, if the person was in the ICU at the time of the diagnosis the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: condition_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the condition that occurred. For example, this could be an ICD10 or Read code.

columns.name: condition_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the condition source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Condition necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using CONDITION_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: condition_status_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the condition status.

source_schema.name: DRGCODES
source_schema.description: Contains diagnosis related groups (DRG) codes for patients.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient hospital stay

columns.name: drg_type
columns.column_description: provides the type of DRG code in the entry

columns.name: drg_code
columns.column_description: contains a code which represents the diagnosis billed for by the hospital

columns.name: description
columns.column_description: provides a human understandable summary of the meaning of the given DRG code

columns.name: drg_severity
columns.column_description: provides additional granularity to DRG codes in the ‘APR’ DRG type

columns.name: drg_mortality
columns.column_description: provides additional granularity to DRG codes in the ‘APR’ DRG type

columns.name: observation_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the OBSERVATION_SOURCE_VALUE and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Observation necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using OBSERVATION_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the unit of the Observation that occurred.

columns.name: qualifier_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the qualifier of the Observation that occurred.

columns.name: observation_event_id
columns.column_description: If the Observation record is related to another record in the database, this field is the primary key of the linked record.

columns.name: obs_event_field_concept_id
columns.column_description: If the Observation record is related to another record in the database, this field is the CONCEPT_ID that identifies which table the primary key of the linked record came from.

columns.name: value_as_datetime
columns.column_description: It is possible that some Observation records might store a result as a date value.

columns.name: drg_code

columns.name: description

target_schema.name: VISIT_DETAIL
target_schema.description: The VISIT_DETAIL table is an optional table used to represents details of each record in the parent VISIT_OCCURRENCE table. A good example of this would be the movement between units in a hospital during an inpatient stay or claim lines associated with a one insurance claim. For every record in the VISIT_OCCURRENCE table there may be 0 or more records in the VISIT_DETAIL table with a 1:n relationship where n may be 0. The VISIT_DETAIL table is structurally very similar to VISIT_OCCURRENCE table and belongs to the visit domain.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit detail.

columns.name: visit_detail_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field contains a concept id representing the kind of visit detail, like inpatient or outpatient. All concepts in this field should be standard and belong to the Visit domain.

columns.name: visit_detail_start_date
columns.column_description: This is the date of the start of the encounter. This may or may not be equal to the date of the Visit the Visit Detail is associated with.

columns.name: visit_detail_end_date
columns.column_description: This the end date of the patient-provider interaction.

columns.name: visit_detail_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to understand the provenance of the visit detail record, or where the record comes from.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: There will only be one provider per visit record and the ETL document should clearly state how they were chosen (attending, admitting, etc.). This is a typical reason for leveraging the VISIT_DETAIL table as even though each VISIT_DETAIL record can only have one provider, there is no limit to the number of VISIT_DETAIL records that can be associated to a VISIT_OCCURRENCE record.

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: This field provides information about the Care Site where the Visit Detail took place.

columns.name: visit_detail_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the kind of visit detail that took place (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, etc.)

columns.name: admitted_from_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: discharge_to_concept_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit detail record. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was discharged to home or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.

columns.name: preceding_visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to find the visit detail that occurred for the person prior to the given visit detail record. There could be a few days or a few years in between.

columns.name: visit_detail_parent_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to find the visit detail that subsumes the given visit detail record. This is used in the case that a visit detail record needs to be nested beyond the VISIT_OCCURRENCE/VISIT_DETAIL relationship.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: Use this field to link the VISIT_DETAIL record to its VISIT_OCCURRENCE.

target_schema.name: DRUG_EXPOSURE
target_schema.description: This table captures records about the exposure to a Drug ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. A Drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a Person it will exert a certain biochemical effect on the metabolism. Drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. Radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as Drugs.

columns.name: drug_exposure_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to records of drug dispensings or administrations for a person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate drugs during the same visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the drug dispensing or administration is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: drug_concept_id
columns.column_description: The DRUG_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies. This is the standard concept mapped from the source concept id which represents a drug product or molecule otherwise introduced to the body. The drug concepts can have a varying degree of information about drug strength and dose. This information is relevant in the context of quantity and administration information in the subsequent fields plus strength information from the DRUG_STRENGTH table, provided as part of the standard vocabulary download.

columns.name: drug_exposure_start_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the start date of the drug record.

columns.name: drug_exposure_end_date
columns.column_description: The DRUG_EXPOSURE_END_DATE denotes the day the drug exposure ended for the patient.

columns.name: verbatim_end_date
columns.column_description: This is the end date of the drug exposure as it appears in the source data, if it is given

columns.name: drug_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: You can use the TYPE_CONCEPT_ID to delineate between prescriptions written vs. prescriptions dispensed vs. medication history vs. patient-reported exposure, etc.

columns.name: stop_reason
columns.column_description: The reason a person stopped a medication as it is represented in the source. Reasons include regimen completed, changed, removed, etc. This field will be retired in v6.0.

columns.name: refills
columns.column_description: This is only filled in when the record is coming from a prescription written this field is meant to represent intended refills at time of the prescription.

columns.name: sig
columns.column_description: This is the verbatim instruction for the drug as written by the provider.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The Provider associated with drug record, e.g. the provider who wrote the prescription or the provider who administered the drug.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The Visit during which the drug was prescribed, administered or dispensed.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the drug exposure occurred. For example, if the person was in the ICU at the time of the drug administration the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: drug_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the drug exposure that occurred. For example, this could be an NDC or Gemscript code.

columns.name: drug_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the drug source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Drug necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using DRUG_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: route_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the drug route.

columns.name: dose_unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the dose unit of the drug given.

source_schema.name: LABEVENTS
source_schema.description: Contains all laboratory measurements for a given patient, including out patient data.

columns.name: subject_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient hospital stay

columns.name: itemid
columns.column_description: Identifier for a single measurement type in the database

columns.name: charttime
columns.column_description: records the time at which an observation was charted, and is usually the closest proxy to the time the data was actually measured

columns.name: value
columns.column_description: contains the value measured for the concept identified by the ITEMID

columns.name: valuenum
columns.column_description: ontains the same data in a numeric format

columns.name: valueuom
columns.column_description: is the unit of measurement for the VALUE

columns.name: flag
columns.column_description: indicates whether the laboratory value is considered abnormal or not, using pre-defined thresholds.

target_schema.name: MEASUREMENT
target_schema.description: The MEASUREMENT table contains records of Measurements, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a Person or Person’s sample. The MEASUREMENT table contains both orders and results of such Measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc. Measurements are stored as attribute value pairs, with the attribute as the Measurement Concept and the value representing the result. The value can be a Concept (stored in VALUE_AS_CONCEPT), or a numerical value (VALUE_AS_NUMBER) with a Unit (UNIT_CONCEPT_ID). The Procedure for obtaining the sample is housed in the PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE table, though it is unnecessary to create a PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE record for each measurement if one does not exist in the source data. Measurements differ from Observations in that they require a standardized test or some other activity to generate a quantitative or qualitative result. If there is no result, it is assumed that the lab test was conducted but the result was not captured.

columns.name: measurement_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to a Measurement record for a Person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate Measurements during the same Visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the measurement is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: measurement_concept_id
columns.column_description: The MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies.

columns.name: measurement_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the date of the measurement.

columns.name: measurement_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Measurement record, as in whether the measurement was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: operator_concept_id
columns.column_description: The meaning of Concept 4172703 for ‘=’ is identical to omission of a OPERATOR_CONCEPT_ID value. Since the use of this field is rare, it’s important when devising analyses to not to forget testing for the content of this field for values different from =.

columns.name: value_as_number
columns.column_description: This is the numerical value of the Result of the Measurement, if available. Note that measurements such as blood pressures will be split into their component parts i.e. one record for systolic, one record for diastolic.

columns.name: value_as_concept_id
columns.column_description: If the raw data gives a categorial result for measurements those values are captured and mapped to standard concepts in the ‘Meas Value’ domain.

columns.name: unit_concept_id
columns.column_description: There is currently no recommended unit for individual measurements, i.e. it is not mandatory to represent Hemoglobin a1C measurements as a percentage. UNIT_SOURCE_VALUES should be mapped to a Standard Concept in the Unit domain that best represents the unit as given in the source data.

columns.name: range_low
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: range_high
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with measurement record, e.g. the provider who ordered the test or the provider who recorded the result.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the Measurement occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Measurement occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: measurement_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the Measurement that occurred. For example, this could be an ICD10 or Read code.

columns.name: measurement_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the MEASUREMENT_SOURCE_VALUE and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Measurement necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the unit of the Measurement that occurred.

columns.name: value_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim result value of the Measurement from the source data .

source_schema.name: MEASUREMENT
source_schema.description: The MEASUREMENT table contains records of Measurements, i.e. structured values (numerical or categorical) obtained through systematic and standardized examination or testing of a Person or Person’s sample. The MEASUREMENT table contains both orders and results of such Measurements as laboratory tests, vital signs, quantitative findings from pathology reports, etc. Measurements are stored as attribute value pairs, with the attribute as the Measurement Concept and the value representing the result. The value can be a Concept (stored in VALUE_AS_CONCEPT), or a numerical value (VALUE_AS_NUMBER) with a Unit (UNIT_CONCEPT_ID). The Procedure for obtaining the sample is housed in the PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE table, though it is unnecessary to create a PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE record for each measurement if one does not exist in the source data. Measurements differ from Observations in that they require a standardized test or some other activity to generate a quantitative or qualitative result. If there is no result, it is assumed that the lab test was conducted but the result was not captured.

columns.name: measurement_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to a Measurement record for a Person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate Measurements during the same Visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the measurement is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: measurement_concept_id
columns.column_description: The MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies.

columns.name: measurement_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the date of the measurement.

columns.name: measurement_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Measurement record, as in whether the measurement was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: operator_concept_id
columns.column_description: The meaning of Concept 4172703 for ‘=’ is identical to omission of a OPERATOR_CONCEPT_ID value. Since the use of this field is rare, it’s important when devising analyses to not to forget testing for the content of this field for values different from =.

columns.name: value_as_number
columns.column_description: This is the numerical value of the Result of the Measurement, if available. Note that measurements such as blood pressures will be split into their component parts i.e. one record for systolic, one record for diastolic.

columns.name: value_as_concept_id
columns.column_description: If the raw data gives a categorial result for measurements those values are captured and mapped to standard concepts in the ‘Meas Value’ domain.

columns.name: unit_concept_id
columns.column_description: There is currently no recommended unit for individual measurements, i.e. it is not mandatory to represent Hemoglobin a1C measurements as a percentage. UNIT_SOURCE_VALUES should be mapped to a Standard Concept in the Unit domain that best represents the unit as given in the source data.

columns.name: range_low
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: range_high
columns.column_description: Ranges have the same unit as the VALUE_AS_NUMBER. These ranges are provided by the source and should remain NULL if not given.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with measurement record, e.g. the provider who ordered the test or the provider who recorded the result.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the Measurement occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Measurement occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: measurement_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the Measurement that occurred. For example, this could be an ICD10 or Read code.

columns.name: measurement_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the MEASUREMENT_SOURCE_VALUE and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Measurement necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using MEASUREMENT_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the unit of the Measurement that occurred.

columns.name: value_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim result value of the Measurement from the source data .

target_schema.name: PERSON
target_schema.description: This table serves as the central identity management for all Persons in the database. It contains records that uniquely identify each person or patient, and some demographic information.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: It is assumed that every person with a different unique identifier is in fact a different person and should be treated independently.

columns.name: gender_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field is meant to capture the biological sex at birth of the Person. This field should not be used to study gender identity issues.

columns.name: year_of_birth
columns.column_description: Compute age using year_of_birth.

columns.name: death_datetime
columns.column_description: This field is the death date to be used in analysis, as determined by the ETL logic. Any additional information about a Person’s death is stored in the OBSERVATION table with the concept_id 4306655 or in the CONDITION_OCCURRENCE .

columns.name: race_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures race or ethnic background of the person.

columns.name: ethnicity_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures Ethnicity as defined by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) of the US Government: it distinguishes only between “Hispanic” and “Not Hispanic”. Races and ethnic backgrounds are not stored here.

columns.name: location_id
columns.column_description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person. Any prior locations are captured in the LOCATION_HISTORY table.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The Provider refers to the last known primary care provider (General Practitioner).

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: The Care Site refers to where the Provider typically provides the primary care.

columns.name: person_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to link back to persons in the source data. This is typically used for error checking of ETL logic.

columns.name: gender_source_value

source_schema.name: PERSON
source_schema.description: This table serves as the central identity management for all Persons in the database. It contains records that uniquely identify each person or patient, and some demographic information.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: It is assumed that every person with a different unique identifier is in fact a different person and should be treated independently.

columns.name: gender_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field is meant to capture the biological sex at birth of the Person. This field should not be used to study gender identity issues.

columns.name: year_of_birth
columns.column_description: Compute age using year_of_birth.

columns.name: death_datetime
columns.column_description: This field is the death date to be used in analysis, as determined by the ETL logic. Any additional information about a Person’s death is stored in the OBSERVATION table with the concept_id 4306655 or in the CONDITION_OCCURRENCE .

columns.name: race_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures race or ethnic background of the person.

columns.name: ethnicity_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field captures Ethnicity as defined by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) of the US Government: it distinguishes only between “Hispanic” and “Not Hispanic”. Races and ethnic backgrounds are not stored here.

columns.name: location_id
columns.column_description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person. Any prior locations are captured in the LOCATION_HISTORY table.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The Provider refers to the last known primary care provider (General Practitioner).

columns.name: care_site_id
columns.column_description: The Care Site refers to where the Provider typically provides the primary care.

columns.name: person_source_value
columns.column_description: Use this field to link back to persons in the source data. This is typically used for error checking of ETL logic.

columns.name: gender_source_value
columns.column_description: This field is used to store the biological sex of the person from the source data. It is not intended for use in standard analytics but for reference only.

columns.name: gender_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: Due to the small number of options, this tends to be zero.

columns.name: dob

columns.name: dod

columns.name: dod_hosp
columns.column_description: is the date of death as recorded in the hospital database

columns.name: dod_ssn

columns.name: hadm_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient hospital stay

columns.name: icustay_id
columns.column_description: is unique to a patient ICU stay

columns.name: startdate
columns.column_description: specify the date period for which the prescription was valid

columns.name: enddate
columns.column_description: specify the date period for which the prescription was valid

columns.name: drug_type
columns.column_description: provides the type of drug prescribed

columns.name: drug
columns.column_description: These columns are various representations of the drug prescribed to the patient

columns.name: drug_name_poe
columns.column_description: These columns are various representations of the drug prescribed to the patient

columns.name: drug_name_generic
columns.column_description: These columns are various representations of the drug prescribed to the patient

columns.name: formulary_drug_cd
columns.column_description: These columns provide a representation of the drug in various coding systems. GSN is the Generic Sequence Number

columns.name: gsn
columns.column_description: These columns provide a representation of the drug in various coding systems. GSN is the Generic Sequence Number

columns.name: ndc
columns.column_description: These columns provide a representation of the drug in various coding systems. GSN is the Generic Sequence Number

target_schema.name: DRUG_EXPOSURE
target_schema.description: This table captures records about the exposure to a Drug ingested or otherwise introduced into the body. A Drug is a biochemical substance formulated in such a way that when administered to a Person it will exert a certain biochemical effect on the metabolism. Drugs include prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vaccines, and large-molecule biologic therapies. Radiological devices ingested or applied locally do not count as Drugs.

columns.name: drug_exposure_id
columns.column_description: The unique key given to records of drug dispensings or administrations for a person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate drugs during the same visit were handled.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the drug dispensing or administration is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: drug_concept_id
columns.column_description: The DRUG_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies. This is the standard concept mapped from the source concept id which represents a drug product or molecule otherwise introduced to the body. The drug concepts can have a varying degree of information about drug strength and dose. This information is relevant in the context of quantity and administration information in the subsequent fields plus strength information from the DRUG_STRENGTH table, provided as part of the standard vocabulary download.

columns.name: drug_exposure_start_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the start date of the drug record.

columns.name: drug_exposure_end_date
columns.column_description: The DRUG_EXPOSURE_END_DATE denotes the day the drug exposure ended for the patient.

columns.name: verbatim_end_date
columns.column_description: This is the end date of the drug exposure as it appears in the source data, if it is given

columns.name: drug_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: You can use the TYPE_CONCEPT_ID to delineate between prescriptions written vs. prescriptions dispensed vs. medication history vs. patient-reported exposure, etc.

columns.name: stop_reason
columns.column_description: The reason a person stopped a medication as it is represented in the source. Reasons include regimen completed, changed, removed, etc. This field will be retired in v6.0.

columns.name: refills
columns.column_description: This is only filled in when the record is coming from a prescription written this field is meant to represent intended refills at time of the prescription.

columns.name: sig
columns.column_description: This is the verbatim instruction for the drug as written by the provider.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The Provider associated with drug record, e.g. the provider who wrote the prescription or the provider who administered the drug.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The Visit during which the drug was prescribed, administered or dispensed.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the drug exposure occurred. For example, if the person was in the ICU at the time of the drug administration the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: drug_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the drug exposure that occurred. For example, this could be an NDC or Gemscript code.

columns.name: drug_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the drug source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Drug necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using DRUG_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

columns.name: route_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the drug route.

columns.name: dose_unit_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the dose unit of the drug given.

source_schema.name: PROCEDUREEVENTS_MV
source_schema.description: Contains procedures for patients

target_schema.name: PROCEDURE_OCCURRENCE
target_schema.description: This table contains records of activities or processes ordered by, or carried out by, a healthcare provider on the patient with a diagnostic or therapeutic purpose.

columns.name: procedure_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: A system-generated unique identifier for each Procedure Occurrence.

columns.name: person_id
columns.column_description: The PERSON_ID of the PERSON for whom the procedure is recorded. This may be a system generated code.

columns.name: procedure_concept_id
columns.column_description: The PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID field is recommended for primary use in analyses, and must be used for network studies. This is the standard concept mapped from the source value which represents a procedure

columns.name: procedure_date
columns.column_description: Use this date to determine the date the procedure occurred.

columns.name: procedure_type_concept_id
columns.column_description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Procedure record, as in whether the procedure was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.

columns.name: modifier_concept_id
columns.column_description: The modifiers are intended to give additional information about the procedure but as of now the vocabulary is under review.

columns.name: quantity
columns.column_description: If the quantity value is omitted, a single procedure is assumed.

columns.name: provider_id
columns.column_description: The provider associated with the procedure record, e.g. the provider who performed the Procedure.

columns.name: visit_occurrence_id
columns.column_description: The visit during which the procedure occurred.

columns.name: visit_detail_id
columns.column_description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the Procedure occurred. For example, if the Person was in the ICU at the time of the Procedure the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.

columns.name: procedure_source_value
columns.column_description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the procedure that occurred. For example, this could be an CPT4 or OPCS4 code.

columns.name: procedure_source_concept_id
columns.column_description: This is the concept representing the procedure source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Procedure necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.
